Correction,: fire water comes from dead plants not animals (common misunderstanding ) .
short explanation : fire water is also called hydrocarbons, the big plant era is called the carbifierious era. ever find (very) old vegetables in your refrigerator? (mushy black nasty) (read turning into a "carbony sugary mess" ever find very old protein in your refrigerator? dried, moldy smelly (not a carbony mess).

Its hard to get hydrocarbons from protein, its easier to get hydrocarbons from plants (for example ethanol from corn) Yes not specifically to a hydrocarbon, but you get my point. no one makes traditional "fire water" out of protein, but it has been made from all sorts of plants.

I don't know if I would want more of this kind of video, but I do find it fascinating. It's very interesting to see this actually put into practice. It's worth pointing out though, that much of this explanation would have been hard to understand without the added visual context clues. Your video was fun to watch, and the presenter has a very nice voice.  I would suggest, however, that your credibility would be improved had you selected a better lexicon to work with.  The expository narration, which you say was prepared using only the 1,000 most commonly used words, in fact includes many words that are in the 10,000 or higher frequency bands of English.  If accuracy matters to you, I recommend that you consult a compact word frequency list called the NGSL.  It reveals the most frequently used 2,400-odd words that constitute 80% of all English word occurrences.  It's a good, free educational reference.  It was recently published and is available online.

I don't know what your process was for making the script, but with some refining this could be an excellent idea. I'd recommend writing the script... Normally... And then "translating" it into simple speech (if you didn't already do it that way). Obviously some of the wording was intentionally dumbed down to fit the word requirement (sky boat), but some of the sentences were legitimately dumbly worded, like you were talking to a child, and that takes away from the credibility of the video. Some of the video started to sound like it was written by a young child trying to make a poem, rather than an educated, adult, native english speaker-- speaking through a lexical funnel. Making a serious didactic video using only common words would make very good videos for classrooms and facebook sharing and whatnot. Also, I'd recommend, although it can be funny, that trying to make up a word to replace what you can't say (upgoer>rocket), is missing the point, and again, dumbing the video down in the bad way. Instead, use a full sentence("a thing, which we use to go up"), or clause, to describe the object, and either directly repeat that sentence to refer to the object, or just use some pronouns. Effective use of pronouns is key here, for both describing and re-referring. You'd think it would sound tedious to repeat a whole sentence, but I think considering the restrictions on what makes up that sentence, it won't seem out of place.
